title: Whinlatter Forest Park Walking and Cycling Route

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Forest trail, Whinlatter Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Forest trail, Whinlatter Forest. Whinlatter Forest has been developed as a major tourist resource, with a number of waymarked trails, such as the one here seen leaving the main B5292 road.

images.title: DM McAtamney [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The summit of the Whinlatter Pass, in Cumbria, and the entrance to the Whinlatter Forest Park.

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Whinlatter Visitor Centre, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Whinlatter Visitor Centre. Whinlatter Forest, whilst still a working plantation, has many kms of tracks, paths marked out for recreational use. The Visitor Centre contains an interpretative display and has interactive activities. as well as the usual tourist sales and services.

images.title: Ian Cunliffe / Track in Whinlatter Forest Park - Skiddaw in the background, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Track in Whinlatter Forest Park - Skiddaw in the background

images.title: Ian Taylor / Hospital Plantation, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hospital Plantation View from the summit of the south loop of the Whinlatter Forest mountain bike trail, on Hospital Fell. Between the conifers is the grassy ridge of Kinn. In the middle distance are (from the left) Swinside (NY2422), Derwentwater and Barrow (NY2221). In the far distance is the snowy Helvellyn ridge.

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Aiken Plantation, Whinlatter, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Aiken Plantation, Whinlatter. There is quite a lot of felling and replantation in this area - to be expected in a working forest.

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Waymarked cycle/walkers route, Winlatter, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Waymarked cycle/walkers route, Winlatter. The Forestry Commission plantations at Winlatter have many waymarked routes for walkers and off-road cyclists.

images.title: Michael Graham / Unexpected Daffodils, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Unexpected Daffodils. Someone's garden escape flowering mid May 1550 feet up in Whinlatter Forest.

description: Enjoy some fantastic walking and cycling trails in this huge park in the Lake District. There are fantastic views of Bassenthwaite Lake, Derwent Water and Keswick as you make your way through the mixed species forest and peaceful glades. The park also has two fantastic purpose built mountain bike trails with cycle hire available within the park. The red graded Altura Trail is a challenging 19 km mountain singletrack, the Quercus Trail is an easier 7.5 km trail. The C2C cycle route also runs through the park so you could continue your ride on the Whitehaven to Keswick or Whitehaven to Penrith cycle route. Walkers can head south of the park and enjoy a climb to Grisedale Pike. It's a popular and challenging climb with wonderful views to the Cumbrian coast, the Vale of Keswick, the Pennines and the head of Derwentwater. On a very clear day you can even see the Belfast Hills and the Southern Uplands of Scotland.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Just to the south you can pick up the Coledale Horseshoe. The popular circular walk starts from the village of Braithwaite, exploring the wonderful hanging valley and visiting several of the area's significant peaks on the way. The route also passes close to Force Crag Mine. The Scheduled ancient monument dates back to the 1800s and is now run by the National Trust. It's an interesting place to visit with information boards detailing the mine's history and some pleasant walks along the Coledale Beck.

display_address: Hobcarton, Whinlatter Pass, Lorton, Cumberland, England, CA13 9UE, United Kingdom
